title: Menetus dilatatus
text:
Menetus dilatatus is a <a href="species">species</a> of small air-breathing <a href="freshwater%20snail">freshwater snail</a>, an <a href="Aquatic%20animal">aquatic</a> <a href="pulmonate">pulmonate</a> <a href="gastropod">gastropod</a> <a href="mollusk">mollusk</a> in the family <a href="Planorbidae">Planorbidae</a>, the <a href="sheep">ram</a>'s horn snails.
Shell description.
The <a href="gastropod%20shell">shell</a> is small, of a yellowish green-color, minutely wrinkled by the lines of growth. The <a href="spire%20%28mollusc%29">spire</a> is flat, composed of 2.5-3 <a href="whorl%20%28mollusc%29">whorls</a>, separated by a well-defined <a href="suture%20%28gastropod%29">suture</a>. The outer whorl has a sharp margin on a level with the spire, diminishing near, but still modifying, the <a href="aperture%20%28mollusc%29">aperture</a>. Below this line the whorl is very convexly rounded so as to encircle a small, deep, abruptly formed <a href="umbilicus%20%28mollusc%29">umbilicus</a>. This whorl rapidly enlarges, and terminates in a very large, not very oblique aperture, with the lip expanded so as to make it trumpet-shaped.
The width of the shell is 2–3 mm. The height of the shell is 0.9 mm.
Distribution.
The species is native to North America. The type locality is <a href="Nantucket%2C%20Massachusetts">Nantucket island</a> and <a href="Hingham%2C%20Massachusetts">Hingham, Massachusetts</a>, USA.
Its non-native distribution includes:
Habitat.
This snail lives in freshwater biotopes.
